the tale of warwick collins reveals the true dogmatic nature of darwin's theory
>Collins studied biology at The University of Sussex, where his tutor was the leading theoretical biologist John Maynard Smith. In 1975 Collins voiced to Maynard Smith the view that natural selection could not drive evolution because it always acted to reduce variation in favour of an optimum type for any environment, whereas the central story of evolution was that of increasing variation and complexity. Collins quoted Charles Darwin in The Origin of Species ("... unless profitable variations do occur, natural selection can do nothing."), and argued that if variation must always occur before natural selection can act, then variation, and not natural selection, drives evolution. He asked Maynard Smith whether he could search for a "strong" theory of variation. Maynard Smith warned Collins that he could not support his efforts to pursue a rival theory to the theory that natural selection drives evolution. Collins replied that he thought the object of science was to question and examine everything, including hallowed theories such as the theory of natural selection. Maynard Smith asserted that, on the contrary, the strength of science was its capacity to agree on certain principles, and act collectively to pursue agreed aims. This difference of view with his tutor made Collins give up his scientific career and pursue other interests instead.

>>15197795
Let me give you an example of how new shit is made.
Lets say, you have a protease or phosphatase enzyme. It has the following functional regions: recognition domain 1, recognition domain 2 and a spring domain. Once recognition region one and two bind a protein, a conformational change activates the spring domain.
If a tranposon, or any other duplication mechanism moves the spring domain into a different gene, say a ligand binding receptor, it will become a new enzyme which can spearate the previously only bound ligand into two.
Add to this that many genes are duplicated and have redundant or inactive copies, you can have new functions quite easely.
This is only one of many mechanisms, by which new proteins, new genes are made, now functions are aquired, etc...
Interestingly, we have evolved to evolve better, so many usefull functional domains and regions and even genes or chromosomal regions are flanked by inverted terminal repeats, or long reathrough transposons, or even inverted transposons. This way genes recombine, form new combinations, new genes, etc...
Pic related, just a quick scetch.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15192895
>I'm skeptical of this
It's half true, half exaggerated for political reasons.
The aboriginals use of fire stick farming did contribute to deforestation, but this isn't unique to Australia. It also happened in the Americas, Asia, the Near East, and Europe. It was fine for small bands but larger societies permanently altered the landscape with it before transitioning to more productive farming techniques. Bronze Age Britain was even less forested than the UK today in part because of this.
Australian deserts also formed due to topography. The driest deserts on earth tend to form at 30 degrees north or south of the equator, which is where most of Australia is, but note Tasmania at 40 degrees south is much more temperate and forested. Combined with having a large inland space (Australia is roughly square) with much less mountains than say, the USA - and the fact that Indonesia gets much of the precipitation that might other fall - its really not surprising so much of Australia is desert. Although IIRC there actually is more savannah and dry grassland than desert proper, that will probably change.
Wish I didn't live here.

>>15191973
ACGIH: The threshold limit value (TLV) is 1 ppm averaged over an 8-hour workshift. Vinyl Chloride is a CARCINOGEN in humans.

HCL: The recommended airborne exposure limit (REL) is 5 ppm, which should not be exceeded at any time. ACGIH: The threshold limit value (TLV) is 2 ppm, which should not be exceeded at any time.

So on the surface, its pretty much the same as to which gas poisons you. . However, the real point isnt which is more toxic, its all about dilution. HCl will be more orders of magnitude dispersed after burning and will therefore have negligible toxicity as opposed to a vapour cloud of vinyl chloride creeping up on you.

Fun fact H2S gas is typically burned to SO2 in flares during process plant emergencies.

It turns out SO2 is more poisonous than H2S (believe it or not) but again, the same logic above applies, because of the heat of combustion and associated gas lift, the SO2 is less harmful.

Dont worry about acid rain you twit, its the least of the issues here. Bit like CO2. .

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15186834
An infinitesimal volume is still a volume. It will not "shrink" down to an area.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15186838
If that's true then you also can't take infinitely many areas and add them together to give a volume. That is, they are tiny volumes added together which we call "Areas", proving my point.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15186882
>then you also can't take infinitely many areas and add them together to give a volume
and you cannot. an integral is NOT a sum, and adding areas does NOT give you a volume, that's precisely why we needed to define a new operation that could do that instead. the core part of the definition of an integral is the factor dx, and in fact what you are doing when you "add" multiple areas together is multiplying those areas by a new factor dx which turns each of those areas to volumes of width dx. in other words, you turn them into volumes before "adding" them up, and THEN you get, unsurprisingly, a volume
as >>15186815 mentioned, you cannot calculate an area with a given interval. if you fix the bounds of the radius of the integral to be the same, all you are doing is asking for the volume of a sphere with equal inner and outer radius, i.e. an empty sphere

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15192126
>Does every ordered field embed into the field of real numbers?
only if it's an archimedean field. a total order can be defined on the field of rational functions over [math]\mathbb{R}[/math] which is not archimedean, so that's an example of a field that does not embed into [math]\mathbb{R}[/math]
>How is this shown or disproved?
you can check for the archimedean property. since we know it's true in [math]\mathbb{R}[/math] (and its ordered subfields), then any ordered field where it doesn't hold can't possibly be embedded into it

however, [math]\mathbb{R}[/math] does contain fields where the archimedean property need not hold, but this would require you to use a different order from the one inherited by [math]\mathbb{R}[/math]. so in the end they are not truly embedded as ordered fields, only as a fields

posts.name: Anonymous

>>15192656
Oh right. Can I ask, if R is reduced, then is it true that x=y if x and y are congruent mod every prime ideal?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15192545
This is the same as claiming that if x is in every prime ideal, then x is 0. Same as claiming that if x is in the intersection of every prime ideal, then x is zero. Same as claiming the intersection of every prime ideal is the zero ideal.
The intersection of every prime ideal is called the nilradical, and is equal to the ideal of all nilpotent elements. So your claim is true if and only if the ring has no nilpotent elements.

It's just a convention. When you write a Lagrangian you do so such that the action is (locally) minimized. You could also write a Lagrangian so that it was maximized instead and the solution to the Euler-Lagrange equation (and hence the physics) would remain unchanged.

posts.com: Is there a way to calculate arbitrary sine and cosine values by hand without having to use infinite series?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15198780
>without having to use infinite series?
why?
well, anyways, sin(x) is the only solution to x''=-x and x(0)=0, so I guess you can use finite differences (numerical ODE) to approximate sin(x).
Subdivide [0,pi] using intervals of size t=pi/n and replace x'' with the discrete version. Now you need to find a sequence a_n such that:
a_0=0, a_n=0
n^2(a_(n+2)- 2a_(n+1)+a_n)=-a_n

For a given n, this is just a linear system which you can solve with a computer.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15198780
Any calculation of sine or cosine for arbitrary values is always going to involve some notion of infinite sequences simply because we are dealing with irrational numbers. You don't have to use a Taylor series though. As far as I understand most calculators use something called the CORDIC algorithm involving an infinite sequence of rotations.

There are two ways you can form opinions about the world, OP.
>you can think "I'm entitled to my opinion" and go from there. After all, people have always told you that you are entitled to your opinions about things.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15196408
This is probably an unpopular opinion, but the Pilot G2 is heavily overrated...not even in the top few pens by the Pilot company.

I ran dozens of pic related dry obtaining my math degree. Pros:
>Water-based ink that dries virtually immediately. *Truly* dry within 1/2 a second...It won't smear whatsoever if you rub your skin over it however hard, such as what happens with oil-based inks (G2 is oil-based I'm pretty certain). This is important if you're left-handed like me.
>Much skinnier nib than the G2. The G2's nib is like a cone, whereas the Precise is more like a short needle, allowing you to see *exactly* what you're doing a bit better (I draw pointillism and similar on ocassion, and this would be much harder with any other kind of nib).
>The ink is *actually liquid*...you can shake it around / make bubbles in it, and it can be kinda fun to play with if you're bored in lecture (they have a little viewing window on both sides of the ink well).
>You can hold it down on the paper in 1 spot, motionless, and it will slowly bleed ink indefinitely (kind of unique/cool as far as everyday pens go)
>Free of the 1/4mm of "wiggle" that a lot of retractable pens have due to their nib not being permanently affixed to the pen body.

Cons:
>The nib is somewhat fragile, and it will bend if the pressure you apply to your writing implement is a standard deviation or two above average. However, if the nib does bend/break, it will not spill ink everywhere.
>Bleeds just a bit on some kinds of paper, preventing you from writing on the back (I never write on the backs of my pages anyway unless it's scrap)
>If you accidentally put it in your pocket without capping it, ink will freely bleed everywhere and destroy your clothes.

>>15181055
Not him, but the real culprit here is negative numbers. If you think imaginary numbers are weird, I don't blame you. But negative numbers are just as weird, we're just conditioned by primary schools to accept them. So the only reasons uninitiated normies think "imaginary" numbers (negative numbers are just a imaginary, as are arguably ALL numbers) are special, is because they're allowed to drop out of math class before getting that far.

You can't have a negative amount of something. You can't travel a negative distance. Negatives only make sense in the context of direction. You can travel a positive distance in a negative direction. "Negative money = debt" means you owe a positive amount of money directed at someone else. Entertaining negative numbers means thinking of them as being on a line, where the positive numbers go one way, and the negative ones go the opposite DIRECTION.

"Imaginary" numbers extend this concept in beyond the line, to a plane, where more than just two directions are possible:
When you multiply positive numbers, the magnitude grows, but the results only ever end up on the right side of the number line. When you multiply negative numbers, the magnitudes multiply as usual, but their "direction" (their sign) flips to the opposite side of the number line (exactly a 180 rotation).

To actually answer your question: If positive multiplication is 360 rotation (ie: no rotation) and negative multiplication is 180, then a 90 rotation is exactly half of whatever a 180 one does. What does that look like? Well, -1 squared is 1 :: 180 * 2 = 360. Whatever the square root of -1 is must correspond to 90. In fact, the square root operation corresponds to finding exactly half the angle on a complex plane. We don't have to stop there either. A cube root corresponds to a third of the angle. We can take any positive root and easily correlate it to some rotation in the complex plane.

As far as e goes, one can rather easily prove that the Taylor series expansion for e^(i*x) equals the Taylor series for cos(x) + i*sin(x)
That particular relationship makes sense when you consider the self-relationship of their derivatives:
>e^(x) is its own derivative
>e^(-x) is its own second derivative
>e^(i*x) is its own fourth derivative
Not so coincidentally:
>cos(x) and sin(x) are ALSO their own fourth derivatives
They can be defined in terms of each other!

To attempt a more qualitative explanation: e as a number relates to continuous self-referentiality, which is relevant here.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15181232
>possible
Yeah. What I just described are called "complex numbers." They're analogous to a 2-dimensional plane and so can be thought of as "2 dimensional" numbers. By the same token, real numbers are analogous to a line and can be thought of as 1-dimensional. Just the positive numbers is a ray.
There's also a system called quaternions that further extends the complex numbers into 4 dimensions.
>useful
Perhaps surprisingly, yes. Because complex numbers fill up a plane, and specific numbers are analogous to various rotations, they encode rotation information numerically. This can actually be very useful to electrical engineers when trying to calculate the interaction of AC currents, since they're sinusoids with a phase. The magnitude of the complex number can encode the voltage while the direction encodes the phase. This is just vector math and doesn't require complex numbers, but depending on the situation, it can be easier to just multiply complex numbers by each other, rather than have to deal with angles and bust out the trig functions.
Quaternions can be used to calculate rotations in 3 dimensions, and are used in video games. Again, you don't HAVE to use them, but real-number implementations with vectors have certain ambiguities that can lead to certain glitches. If you've ever seen a player's head or arm in the FIFA games ridiculously rotate into itself before settling back in place, it may be because the programmers didn't use quaternions.

>>15182936
>someone else is going to have to explain it
circular motion around the origin can be defined by the property that the radius vector is always orthogonal to the velocity (tangent) vector. this leads to the differential equation in the complex plane

dz/dt = i*z

more generally, for any complex number K we can consider the equation

dz/dt = K * z

solution satisfying z(0) = 1 is denoted e^Kt. it is a spiral motion where the radius grows exponentially. if K is real, solution is the usual real exponential. if K is imaginary, solution is a circular motion.

if you write the equation for the circular motion dz/dt = i*z in components (i.e. z = x + i*y), you get

dx/dt = -y
dy/dt = x

solution is of course

x = cos(t)
y = sin(t)

which shows that

e^ix = cos(t) + i*sin(t)

>>15181704
It is. The angle of 1 in degrees is:
0 = 360 = 720 = 1080 = 1440 = ...
The square root operation takes half the angle, which corresponds to:
0, 180, 360, 540, 720, ...
Using the equivalence of angles to simplify gives:
0, 180, 360, 180, 360, ...
Finally, converting these angles back to their associated number gives:
1, -1, 1, -1, 1, ...
And look at that. 1 and -1 are the two possible square roots of 1.

>>15189455
It's both. Roots have multiple answers. An equivalent question is, "What angle can I add to itself 3 times, to get 180 degrees?"
The first and most obvious answer is 60. But note that 180 added to itself 3 times is ALSO 180, because angles wrap around on themselves.
180 = 540 = 900 = 1260 = 1620 = 1980 = ...
Dividing by 3 yields:
60, 180, 300, 420, 540, 660, ...
Simplify:
60, 180, 300, 60, 180, 300, ...
So, you see, there are 3 unique answers. 0.5 + 0.87 i, -1, and 0.5 - 0.87 i

sqrt(1) = 1. but also sqrt(1) = -1. but 1 =/= -1.

>>15199267
ChatGPT: According to the theory of special relativity, length contraction occurs in a moving object relative to an observer in an inertial frame. However, the length contraction of the string hanging between two spaceships would depend on the direction of the acceleration.

In the frame of reference of the spaceships, the string would not appear to shorten, as both spaceships would be moving at the same velocity and the string would still be the same length as it was in the rest frame.

In the frame of reference of an observer in an inertial frame, such as the frame S you mentioned, the string would appear to shorten due to length contraction. However, this does not necessarily mean that the string would snap. The strength of the string would also be affected by its material properties, such as its tension, elasticity, and maximum strain, as well as any external forces that may be acting on it.

It is important to note that the effects of special relativity, including length contraction, become significant at high speeds close to the speed of light. At lower speeds, the effects are negligible.

>The first documented systematic technique capable of determining integrals is the method of exhaustion of the ancient Greek astronomer Eudoxus (ca. 370 BC), which sought to find areas and volumes by breaking them up into an infinite number of divisions for which the area or volume was known.[1] This method was further developed and employed by Archimedes in the 3rd century BC and used to calculate the area of a circle, the surface area and volume of a sphere, area of an ellipse, the area under a parabola, the volume of a segment of a paraboloid of revolution, the volume of a segment of a hyperboloid of revolution, and the area of a spiral.[2]
(NOTE: 700 year time gap)
>A similar method was independently developed in China around the 3rd century AD by Liu Hui, who used it to find the area of the circle. This method was later used in the 5th century by Chinese father-and-son mathematicians Zu Chongzhi and Zu Geng to find the volume of a sphere.[3]
>In the Middle East, Hasan Ibn al-Haytham, Latinized as Alhazen (c.965 – c.1040 AD) derived a formula for the sum of fourth powers.[4] He used the results to carry out what would now be called an integration of this function, where the formulae for the sums of integral squares and fourth powers allowed him to calculate the volume of a paraboloid.[5]

posts.name: Beth

>>15198700

Sure thing, here's a beginner friendly introduction to the research I'm doing:

Let's start with the basics.

-Gravity is one of the fundamental forces in the universe. You can think of gravity as "mass attracts mass". It's why the Earth is in orbit around the Sun and why apples fall to the ground.

-Plasma is a state of matter where the atoms are so hot that the atoms that make it up literally seperate. Most of the ordinary matter we see in the universe is plasma.

-At very high temperatures, like in the centers of stars, the particles that make up plasma start to behave very strangely. Protons adopt a special state, known as "Volkoff spin".

-Volkoff spin isn't a very intuitive concept to grasp, but in essence it's consequence of proton hyperresonance in a charged non-Euclidean fluid. These effects were predicted by B. I. Karachensetov in the late 1990s, but they're are very hard to replicate in the laboratory. In theory, it's possible to approximate these effects by placing a tessellated Si-Ni-Co crystal under a running Hansen-Vogel field and reflecting any M-radiation emitted through an epsilon-concave surface and then feeding the spectrum through a computer analysis.

-Electrons in this state deform and rapidly switch between a 3-sphere a hypertorus topology, with a fractional-dimensional form somewhere in between. Surprisingly enough, electron charge doesn't have a complex Hegel value anywhere in this state.

-Electrons are very small particles of matter that surround the nucleus of the atom and carry negative charge. When electrical current flows, those are electrons moving.

There you are! Feel free to ask for clarification.

>In the 12th century, Latin translations of his textbook on arithmetic (Algorithmo de Numero Indorum) which codified the various Indian numerals, introduced the decimal positional number system to the Western world. >In addition to his best-known works, he revised Ptolemy's Geography, listing the longitudes and latitudes of various cities and localities. He further produced a set of astronomical tables and wrote about calendaric works, as well as the astrolabe and the sundial. He also made important contributions to trigonometry, producing accurate sine and cosine tables, and the first table of tangents.

>Perhaps one of the most significant advances made by Arabic mathematics began at this time with the work of al-Khwarizmi, namely the beginnings of algebra. It is important to understand just how significant this new idea was. It was a revolutionary move away from the Greek concept of mathematics which was essentially geometry. Algebra was a unifying theory which allowed rational numbers, irrational numbers, geometrical magnitudes, etc., to all be treated as "algebraic objects". It gave mathematics a whole new development path so much broader in concept to that which had existed before, and provided a vehicle for future development of the subject. Another important aspect of the introduction of algebraic ideas was that it allowed mathematics to be applied to itself in a way which had not happened before.

posts.com:
[math]\to[/math]
should be used to denote logical implications.

[math]\implies[/math]
should be used to denote metamathematical or informal implications.

[math]T\vdash P[/math]
or just [math]\vdash P[/math], if the context is clear or left up in the air, should be used for formal provability claims.

[math]\frac{P}{Q}[/math]
should be used to denote imposed inference rules and rewriting principles.
This includes principles like Bayes rule when adopted as a principle. (The latter is not to be confused with Bayes law proven as just a basic factoring result in measure theory, and so for essentially combinatorical situations just as applicable in frequentist applications)

Those should not ever be mixed.

the empty theory is certainly consistent since any structure models it (vacuously, as the theory is empty)
it's most definitely not complete though. take for example the language with one binary relation symbol only; we can neither prove nor disprove that the relation is reflexive as we can come up with easy countermodels in each case (one where the interpretation of that relation symbol is reflexive and one where it isn't). again, those are actual models of our theory because they vacuously satisfy it

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15196881
Intuitively, the pullback diagram allows us to determine whether a given morphism "lands inside" a subobject S by comparing the image of the morphism under the subobject classifier with the terminal object. If it does, we say that the subobject S "classifies" the morphism f. The definition of subobject classifier involving a pullback diagram thus provides a convenient and natural way to describe subobjects and their relationships with morphisms

>>15197713
It divergers for every [math]z[/math] with [math]|z|=1[/math]. Just consider the sequence of partial sums
[eqn]s_k = \sum_{n=1}^k z^{n!}[/eqn]
for a given [math]z[/math]. It can't be a Cauchy sequence since
[eqn]|s_{k+1} - s_k| = 1[/eqn]
for all [math]k[/math].

posts.name: Anonymous

>>15197139
ah, thanks so much. I think this made me understand.
In [math]\mathbf{Set}[/math] the property of the characteristic function can be stated as [eqn]\forall b \in B \;(b \in A \Leftrightarrow \chi(b) = \text{true})[/eqn]
Using the preimage, this can be more compactly stated like this
[eqn]A=\chi^{-1}(\text{true})[/eqn]
So the property really translates to "A is the preimage of true under the characteristic function".
I'll be honest that I already forgot what the text taught me about preimages in general categories, but I believe it was related to pullbacks in some way.

Thanks for pointing me in the right direction.

I had many of the autism symptoms as a child, I kind of developed a meta-obsession over why I think differently and I was in my head so much I pretty much eventually became able to change the way I think and miraculously improve just by willing it in my head.

Like in 5th grade I kept on accidentally skipping questions on tests, after the teacher discussed it with my parents I just thought about not skipping questions harder and miraculously stopped skipping them. I also became fully ambidextrous with my feet on a whim when I was 10 years old during an indoor soccer match, I just instinctively took a shot with my left when my right was blocked and afterwards just had a realization that I could kick with my left.

I was limited by my awareness of being able to improve at something and awareness wasn't a strong suit of mine as my brain just worked without my conscious awareness often. I remember many insignificant moments or thoughts to myself extremely well only for me to only to realize something significant about that thought several years later, I also can just remember regular things without paying conscious attention to it. I also have an internal alarm clock, even if I have to get up at a time very different from my sleep schedule, I will always wake up exactly at that time without an alarm, even if I want to just sleep through the thing as long as I know that it's happening I will wake up on time.

Over the years I slowly managed to fix all the little autistic behaviors I had and after a while essentially I had become able to function completely the same as a normal person.

It's a shame that I'll never not sound ridiculous and delusional describing all that I just did and I can't really say I'm not, as all these years the main driving force behind everything I strived for was to be and appear normal with now there being no proof that I'm not to anyone but myself.

>>15180491
>What you are doing to survive the incoming recession edition.

Most recession-resistant industries, in the sense that they have the least unemployment during recessions are:

1) Government: This makes sense because the government does not give a shit about the current economic environment. They don't sell products to consumers, they just print money, so they do not do layoffs in the same way that companies do.

2) Healthcare: This makes sense as during tough economic times, people die more. Therefore you have more work.

3) Finance: Tough financial times just means you need better financial managers so this adds up.

4) Consumer Staples: These are products that everyone needs/wants even during the toughest times. Could even include some luxury consumer goods if there is already an existing wealthy consumer base that will support it.

5) IT: Our world runs in tech so it makes sense that you need the people to still manage these systems.

If you work in one of these industries, or are somehow attached, you may be safer than others. However, there is one other rule to follow: do not be TOO specialized. For example, IT is one of the most recilient industries. That may seem weird when you look at the current wave of layoffs however you have to realize that the layoffs are mainly coming for highly skilled engineers that are simply not needed right now. There are just a limited amount of cutting-edge tech products to work on right now. However, the guy that simply maintains the database is still very much needed. Same thing for the guy who installs PowerPoint on Stacy's computer (Stacy is still not going to learn how computers work).

No I don't have a masters, but I can tell you that NOT having one has definitely been career limiting for me and I deeply regret not just sticking it out in college for an extra year or so to get it out of the way. I waffle on whether going back now would be worth it.

Only real advice I can give you is always be looking for that next little merit badge, whether a PE, a LEED certification, lean six sigma, whatever. It adds up after a few years. Also don't burn bridges, make friends, be customer facing, don't be "that" engineer. I get contract work on the side because I'm pretty even keel and don't sperg out when things go sideways. That's worth a lot. Your reputation matters almost as much, if not more, than your credentials because as you get deeper and deeper into your field you are going to find that its probably smaller than you think and that guy you saw 5 years ago may end up being your next boss or potential customer.

It's about how good you are. You can be successful or a failure in any career it's not easy to predict. Work hard in any of those degrees, build a good reputation and you will make money in an interesting job.

EE is generally good because it has a lot of credits and the PE exam after will allow you more directly negotiate for a job (i.e. it'd easy to get a job as an EE if you are an EE). This doesn't just mean good grades, force yourself out of your comfortzone and do a proper traineeship. Then you will be alright.

>>15184974
That's the case for theoretical ("pure") math. If you study applied mathematics then it's an entirely different ballgame (in most colleges applied maths overlaps significantly with comp sci, and you'll even find that they're in the same program in places like Brown).
You'll be wanting to take some applied math courses as electives anyway if you take CS or EE, knowing statistics and how to code is extremely helpful for most jobs and makes it easier to pivot into a data science/analyst role or get into research. Operations Research is also an applied maths field that's great to take in general.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15191056
>Is H-index a good way to gauge how good a potential advisor is?
Not really. It's a flawed metric for evaluating research productivity, and for your advisor you want research productivity but also other qualities. Such as not being a psychopath, having funding and contacts today rather than 25 years ago, and having their group do and publish interesting research rather than dishing out a dozen middle author garbage papers per month. It will naturally favor old, established professors over young group leaders who may well be doing more impactful work today.

All that said, it is not an entirely meaningless metric and if you had to condense someone's research output into one number it's hard to do better.

>The one I'm looking at has an H-index of 6, and he's been teaching for 25 years.
That is truly pathetic regardless of the field. I have an h-index of 5 and I don't even have my PhD yet.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15193883
Yes, those are some of the qualities that many people find unappealing in research. The flip side is that you usually have a lot more freedom in your topics and approach. Also you get to work on things which aren't anywhere near being used in industry; this also means that you're not shipping a product anytime soon so if it doesn't work then you just get a less flashy paper out of it. The downsides you mention follow almost necessarily from this.

AI is very different from my field, but generally research is not just about getting the best-performing device or whatever. If you can do that then you'll make some very high-impact publications and boost your career, but even without it your work can be interesting (and fulfilling) if it advances knowledge and understanding.

I personally don't mind the job itself, but the the sheer shittiness of the career path is what is turning me away from research. Basically requires sacrificing everything for low-paid temporary contracts that almost certainly will never lead anywhere.

I'm job hunting for my (admittedly small) niche involving the application of AI to my area, and I'm getting a lot of interviews. It could very much be the way you are framing your experience isn't right, or that you're not optimally hunting for job listings. Are you reaching out to hiring managers/recruiters or cold applying? For post PhD level jobs it is much easier to do it that way, as they can put a face to the name, and the actual qualified candidate pool is so small that having met with or talked to the hiring people in some way is a huge advantage.

The current project , dubbed the Star-H,
aims to establish as realistic as possible a database concerning launch vehicles with air breathing propulsion . The concept considered in the first phase of study was a relatively conservative one ,
but one that was intended to be feasible with the technologies at hand at the end of the coming decade , chiefly developed for Hermes.
- the first stage has air breathing propulsion designed by SNECMA/SEP/ONERA,
- the second, throw-away stage uses a cryogenic engine derived from the HM60/Vulcain , propelling an orbital vehicle

With turbo-rocket engines,this vehicle wouldweight 400 tonnes at take off.The first stage weighs140 tonnes empty and carries 140 tonnes of propellant (LH2 and LOX). The second stage and orbiter together weigh 120 tonnes at separation and carry 90 tonnes of propellant (also LH2 and LOX).
The main technical problems have been analyzed on a basic project of this type and have revealed the technologies needed,in particular as concerns the structure and the integration of the propulsion.

1989, National Aerospace Plane Conference - French space plane research, from Hermes to transatmospheric vehicles

It seems you are thinking way too much about this. One possibility, like I reckon they did in the movie Contact, is just showing some dots each representing a unit and then putting them together in an specific way so that one can visually deduce that there's some kind of mathematical operation going on. In each row you'd use these dots and then add whatever sign you come up with in between them, any kind of intelligent species would eventually get that you are adding them up. Once that is done, keep on adding new signs until you describe a pretty intensive list of arithmetical concepts, and then go on and on on, each sign that the aliens just learnt would be useful for the next step. Now you at least share some common language. Next step depends on what your goal and what do you want to communicate about. I suppose it would be current location and technology exchange, which would all still be communicated using this method, but just add graphs this time.

posts.com:
>>15191392
It's ultra rational and easy: for a human being in nature if you see something that's EXACTLY a human face and you can clearly make it out, then it's no biggie, because its a human you know how to interact with and if there's danger you have time to prepare.
If it's something that sort of looks like a face or you have trouble making it out, even if it's really close then there's not many options:
1)It's an animal (either in concealment or not)
2)its a human in some sort of concealment.
3)it's a human with a serious problem (one that could happen to you)

All of those mean possible imminent danger, so it's no wonder evolving the reflex to get extremely unerved and ready for the worse when the brain makes out the "similar to a face but not quite" is detected.

I've used more beds than I can count. Box spring, Japanese futon, air mattress hard floor, purple. The absolute best is a waterbed. It disperses weight the best and leaves you in comfort. They are heated which further relaxed your muscles and conserves energy. You wake up as you went to sleep, spread out and relaxed. If you don't have much body fat, it's easy to wake up curled up in a conventional mattress and more blankets are no solution as you'll overheat. They faded in popularity as landlords began banning them and home construction went downhill in quality. There's a study showing improvements in insomnia and falling asleep quicker. I'm somewhat surprised there's not more research on them and bed types in general.

The reason redditors dislike them is that they are bad for multiple sleepers and sex. It you're on your own, it's objectively the best. It's also very anxiolytic, feels like you're enveloped in comfort.

https://www.drugdiscoverynews.com/what-now-for-the-amyloid-hypothesis-15611
>In July 2022, a bombshell dropped on the Alzheimer's disease research field. For years, researchers had searched for something that caused the disease’s telltale amyloid plaques — complex tangles of a protein called amyloid-beta (Aβ) frequently found in the brains of patients with neurodegenerative disorders. A series of studies published starting in the mid-2000s reported the discovery of a toxic form of Aβ in the brains of mouse models of Alzheimer's disease called Aβ*56. Researchers hoped that Aβ*56 was the protein that snowballed into those amyloid plaques. But a team of sleuths found that many of the papers describing Aβ*56 were fraudulent and contained an array of faked images and blots. The fraud seemed to call the entire idea of amyloids causing Alzheimer’s disease into question.

>Why do we lose appetite when we are sick?
Fever causes loss of appetite since fever kills off much of the beneficial bacteria in the intestines, making it harder to digest food and food is more likely to go rancid and only partially digested in the intestines then, which is very bad (body rejects that food by collecting water in the intestines and explosive diarreah expelling it).

The loss of water and general problems caused by food in the intestines during fever sickness is why the body signals the brain to reduce appetite by releasing certain hormones and blocking certain neurotransmitters.

Cause of the old saying, "Starve a Fever, Feed a Cold".

>>15196782
It really depends on your interests as a mathematician. If you want to study algebraic geometry or algebraic number theory, refer to the list below. If you want to study differential geometry, realistically you'll only need some homological algebra to deal with (co)homology theories and some abstract group theory to deal with Lie groups, but you'll learn most of what you'll need along the way. If you're into analysis, I guess the right flavour of analysis may require a lot of algebra, but you realistically won't need much of it.

For group theory there are many resources, I studied from Herstein and liked it.

For commutative ring theory
>Atiyah Macdonald
I'll shill it all day, true masterpiece. Do as many exercises as you can.
The first time around you should skip the later chapters, a good goal is to do chapters 1 to 4, 5 up to the going-up, and then chapters 6-8. The rest will be for another time.

Now you should have a solid foundation. If you stumble into some topic you still don't know (notable ones include dimension theory, regularity, kahler differentials, homological algebra), first try to see if AM covers it, otherwise there are plenty of valid choices, I personally like
>Matsumura
can be terse
>Eisenbud
can be verbose
>Weibel
the go to for homological algebra, imho

Other stuff:
>Marcus
down to earth way of learning algebraic number theory. I think it's very instructive to learn both how these results can be done by hand, and how they follow from the general theory (which you should be able to do on your own, as an exercise)
>Local fields
more serious book on algebraic number theory, beautifully written
>Hartshorne
not an algebra book, but after you've learnt the first 8 chapters of AM and some dimension theory, you're ready to learn algebraic geometry (looking up stuff you don't know along the way)

Analysts study semigroups of operators. I'm not an analyst, but my understanding is that you have a bunch of operators with various commutation rules, and they're usually not invertible, so they form a semigroup. I think this illustrates the situation one might find https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/K%C3%A4hler_identities#The_identities
In dynamical systems one often considers the action of a semigroup, but I think they're mostly interested in the case of [math]\mathbb{N} [/math].
In probability, one studies stochastic processes, and often the index set [math]T [/math] is closed under addition, so it makes for a semigroup. Again, I don't think they usually consider fancy stuff.
In the study of ultrafilters, one uses Ellis's lemma to show that there exist idempotent ultrafilters.

These are all the situations in which I encountered semigroups during my formation, but I'm into algebraic geometry which doesn't appear to use them, so idk how much these examples are meaningful

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15197586
>I'm into algebraic geometry which doesn't appear to use them
Semigroups are super important in algebraic geometry, they usually appear as exponents in polynomials. I will give three examples in which they appear:


1) Toric varieties: In many spaces you have "global coordinates" and the functions over the space can be understood in terms of them. This happens with affine spaces, projective spaces (homogeneous coordinates/polynomials), product of projective spaces (bi-homogeneous coordinates/polynomials),...
A very general notion of space with coordinate is given by the notion of Toric variety. For a semigroup S, this is the space in which functions are exactly elements on the semigroup-algebra k[S], that is, Spec k[S]. If S is generated by elements x,y,z,... then these elements are your "coordinates".

2) Okounkov bodies: A big problem in algebraic geometry is to understand line bundles and their sections. The Riemann-Roch problem asks for understanding the sections H^0(X,L^n) for all the powers L^n of L. You can do this buy fixing a notion of order of vanishing on X (you can do this by fixing a flag of subvarieties on X and taking order of vanishings along the flag). Using this, you can see which order of vanishings appear on H^0(X,L^n) for different n. This list of vectors gives you a semigroup that depends only on L. You can recover all the intersection theory of L by doing geometry with this semigroup. (This is the theory of Okounkov-bodies and their mixed volumes).

3) Algebraic geometry of curves: Given a curve C and a point P on C, the Weierstrass semigroup of C at P is the set of all natural numbers k for which there exist a function regular outside P with a pole of order exactly k at P. It is an open problem to classify which semigroups can appear as the Weiestrass semigroup of a curve.

causality is the question of whether, and how the future is decided by past events. if you reject determinism then you can't have causality. because rejecting determinism then implies each moment in time is simply its own new unique, standalone, fundamental thing. there is no linkage aka causal mapping between each moment.

within determinism, there are different models of causality put forward. spacetime causality used by einstein is the most plausible one, in my opinion.

locality is the assumption that:

"to transfer information from one space-time region to another, disjoint, region, the same information has to also be present on any closed (3-dimensional) surface surrounding the first region."

i took this definition from sabine's paper. importantly, this is not the definition of locality used in bell's theorem; bell locality is something different (and this confusion of different definitions has created issues)

you're welcome for the free education.

>>15197176
i still don't understand how it depends. please concisely explain how it depends.

the reason counterfactuals are so crucial in this debate, is because statistical independence "implicitly draws on counterfactual situations, mathematical possibilities that we do not observe and that, depending on one's model or theory, may or may not exist."

in fact the other two assumptions of bell's theorem also invoke counterfactuals:

"The issue of whether Factorization is a suitable way to encode locality and causality is similar to the issue with interpreting Statistical Independence: It draws on alternative versions of reality that may not ever actually occur. Factorization requires us to ask what the outcome of a measurement at one place would have been given another measurement elsewhere (Outcome Independence) or what the setting of one detector would have been had the other detector's setting been different (Parameter Independence). These are virtual changes, expressed as state-space perturbations. The changes do therefore not necessarily refer to real events happening in space-time."

(quotes from palmer and hossenfelder)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15198462
What affects an aircraft’s sonic boom is its mach number (the ratio of the aircraft’s speed to the speed of sound). Suppose an aircraft is flying at 20 times the speed of sound, so M = 20, which is possible for whatever these UFOs are to achieve. The sound waves form a cone behind the aircraft. Let’s call the angle between the aircraft and the cone formed by the sound waves x. The relationship between the angle x and mach number M is sin(x) = 1/M. If the mach number is 20, solving for x gives x = arcsin(1/20) which is approximately 0.05 radians (an incredibly tiny angle). This could explain why no sonic boom is heard from these aircrafts because the angle between the cone and the aircraft is incredibly tiny. You can’t hear the aircraft if you’re outside this cone.

posts.com:
>>15191712
>We can't be the only life
Sure, but what percentage of life (carbon-based, organic, aka the stuff we most often consider to be alive) is advanced enough to be relevant? Most people think that Earth-like life is all about a suitable star, habitable zone, and a planet with the right mix of elements. It's so much more than that. The planet's core must be suitable to generate a field that protects the planet from solar wind etc. Greenhouse effect must be optimal to support life, but not too much to stifle it. And then, we humans would not be there if an optimally sized meteorite hadn't destroyed the previous, more primitive dominant creature of the planet. Not to mention that we have populated just the right places (tectonic activity) where our ancestors were forced down from the trees and thus, evolution happened to guide us toward a bigger brain future. Adding together all the happenstances, the probability of human-like life to appear elsewhere is pretty small. That said, it is possible that other life forms (e.g. dinos) could have evolved to intelligence eventually. It's also possible that any other life forms (non-carbon based, inorganic, immaterial even) can evolve to have relevant levels of intelligence (shit like magnetic monopoles on cosmic strings inside the belly of stars).

In other words: as we go up in complexity and intelligence (level of consciousness), the less likely that it occurs (the less there are out there in absolute numbers). It is truly possible that we're the only ones in vicinity who can think, build and leave the atmosphere of our home planet.

Furthermore, I can easily sympathize with both the "life is rare, and perhaps unique" side and the "life is everywhere" side too. I believe it would be useful to visualize these factors on a graph. On y you have the "Factors of Difference compared to Life on Earth" and on x you have the "Likelihood of Emergence". For instance, Earth-like life with opposite chirality OR constituting of antimatter, rather than matter, is more believable (and thus more likely to appear) than the aforementioned monopoles stuff. Non-carbon based living chemistry is imho less likely than the mirror-chirality stuff, but it could still happen, albeit it would come with a lot of constraints (nothing is as versatile as C-based afawk). Then comes all the other wild imagination stuff: life in interstellar dust+plasma, life in quark-gluon plasma, life on neutron stars, etc...
So while C-based life may not be the sole contestant, in the grand scheme of things, it may very well be the most likely and most versatile one.

If I am a wave with two perpendicular waves and each wave is able to rotate, then the total degree of rotation would depend on the phase difference between the waves. If the waves are in phase (i.e., their peaks and troughs line up), then the total degree of rotation would be 360 degrees for each wave, or 720 degrees in total. However, if the waves are out of phase (i.e., their peaks and troughs are offset), then the total degree of rotation would be less than 720 degrees, and would depend on the specific phase difference between the waves.

>>15194807
the commutative property of multiplication means you can eliminate almost half of the table
the identity properties of 0 and 1 mean you can eliminate those rows and columns
the properties of base 10 make 10 and its powers simply decimal shifts (with shift distance equal to the power)
then, memorize what's left row by row until you reach the largest row you expect to assist you. many rows have helpful shortcuts as well (example: multiplying x by 5 is just ((1/2)*(x/10))*10)

you should also look into prime factorization, which will provide additional exercise in analyzing how various numbers can be composed (think of it like coming at the problem from the opposite direction)

1 Start with small numbers first.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Just considering 0 through 9 since you should know the methods for multiplying multiple digit numbers.

Times 0 and times 1 are trivial.
Times 2 you should know from addition.
Times 5 and times 9 follow simple patterns.
For times 3, multiply by 2 and add one more.
For times 4, double twice.
For times 6, multiply by 5 and add one more.
The remaining three facts: 7*7=49, 7*8=56, and 8*8=64 can be calculated (times 8 is doubling three times or subtracting twice from 10 and times 7 is adding twice to times 5), but may be easier to just memorize.

Practice using mental arithmetic whenever the opportunity arises or you'll forget everything. With enough practice, you'll start to remember the results without having to thing about them.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15197584
Another method good for the larger ones like 7*7, not as well known:
Add them and subtract 10 to get the tens place: 7+7-10 = 4
Multiply their differences from 10 to get the ones place: 3*3 = 9

As someone who knows these already off the top of my head, it seems like more work than necessary, but when working out multiplication problems in hexadecimal it works well for me, so you might find it useful.

>Is the speed of light arbitrary?
no
>If not, what is the derivation?
it's calculated from the permittivity and permeability of the given medium
for a so-called "vacuum" that's called the "permittivity of free space" and the "permeability of free space" respectively (epsilon_0 and mu_0)
the speed of light is given by:
>c = 1 / sqrt(epsilon_0 * mu_0)
neat, huh?
>If so, what would be the implications if say, the speed of light were double, triple or even a hundred times faster what it is.
that would mean you would have found a way to reduce the permittivity and/or permeability by the factor necessary for this to occur
at this point it's not known if it's even possible to reduce those values beyond their "vacuum" values, but it could be
>In other words, assuming the figure is a finite number, would "changing" the speed of light break any fundamental laws?
not really, but it would probably require extremely advanced technology
you'd have to set up a "highway" of sorts for the light, a path where the permittivity and permeability were lower than that of "vacuum"

posts.com:
The speed of light, by which I assume you mean the speed of light in a vacuum, is arbitrary as far as we know, in that we can't determine it without physical measurements. It might be possible to derive it from first principles with more advanced physics, nobody knows. You can say it's related to the permittivity and permeability, but those are just two more constants. What makes them more fundamental than c? Nothing. It's also related to other constants like the fine structure constant. If the speed of light were different it would change a lot of things about the structure of the universe. In terms of fundamental physical laws, changing c is just changing a parameter. The effect is straightforward. However, in terms of complex matter like what we're made of, the changes would be very unpredictable and almost impossible to predict, except perhaps for a very small change in c. This is because changing c would affect every level of physics and chemistry in various ways. For instance, it would change the masses and stability of all the elements, as well as their chemistry and other behaviour.
>https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dimensionless_physical_constant

The problem is that we think EVs are a replacement for gas vehicles when they're not. EVs can only replace like 1% of the vehicles on the road, and even then after that happens we'll need costly recycling infrastructure to deal with them. Not to mention the costs of all this to 3rd world countries puts them far, far beyond viability. While EVs have decreased pollution and increased compatibility with renewable tech, both of which are good, they're no silver bullet to global warming. I see companies talking about "the long task of electrifying the 1st world", that will not happen. There are billions of cars on the road, it's just not possible to replace all those.

We are walking into a collapse. Clean air standards are spurring automaker companies to make vehicles more and more complex to meet those standards, which elevate maintenance and purchasing costs for people. At the same time EVs are not a viable alternative. We'll either have to let automaker companies collapse, or get rid of the standards and just admit there's nothing we can do about global warming and deal with the consequences, which might be a thousand times worse a decade from now. Shit's whack yo, I don't even thing the most rabid EV fanboy admits that the technology can replace autos, it's always "it'll take decades to do" when in reality it's just straight up unfeasible.

>>15188413
I have a Skywatcher Heritage 130p with plenty of accessories. Got it for 100$ like new, it was one of the best purchases I've ever did. Truly a bargain and the first time I did some star hopping it was a mesmerizing experience.

A few tips for the newbies:
- Always get a dobsonian. It's the best one price/quality-wise, because the money that doesn't get spent in a flimsy mount, actually goes to the telescope itself. Also, you spend less to have more aperture, which is key.
- Ideally you want to spend a lot of money for eyepieces, so don't be stingy on the telescope itself.
- Never buy a telescope from a supermarket.
- Bird-jones optical designs / spherical mirrors are fucking worthless.
- Parabolic mirrors are peak design.
- Tracking DSOs, planets, etc. manually is how chads do it. Pussies use go-tos right from the start.
- Light pollution is your worst enemy, so don't overspend in a telescope if you live in a place with Bortle level of 8 or something. Check this: https://www.lightpollutionmap.info/

posts.sub: How the fuck does lightning work?
posts.com:
I'm trying to understand the natural processes that lead to static discharge in the direction of cloud to ground. Here is my understanding so far, feel free to correct anything I have wrong. Assume we're talking in terms of electron flow, not conventional flow.

1) The triboelectric effect (basically friction as I understand) occurs in storm clouds when water and ice molecules collide with each other. The direction that the involved water and ice molecules are moving causes an accumulation of negative charge in middle and lower region of the cloud, and positive charge in higher region of the cloud (the anvil).

2) The negatively charged lower region of the cloud induces a positive charge on the surface of the Earth directly below it, creating an electric field between those regions.

3) At some point the difference in electric charge becomes too great and the air fails as an insulator. When that happens, the electrons in the cloud rush to ground -> lightning

My questions:
>In step 2: If a positive charge is induced on the Earth's surface, where do the repelled (from the surface) electrons go once the absence of electrons is "filled" by the lightning (the electrons from the cloud)
>In step 3: Does the air at the point of "failing to be an insulator" become a conductor?
>Some sources have referenced a small area of positive charge at the absolute bottom of the cloud (see gif related), but their explanations didn't help - how is this small layer of positive charge relevant?

>I'm trying to understand the natural processes that lead to static discharge in the direction of cloud to ground.
lightning can strike in both directions, both air-to-ground and ground-to-air
air-to-ground is the most common, though
>>In step 2: If a positive charge is induced on the Earth's surface, where do the repelled (from the surface) electrons go once the absence of electrons is "filled" by the lightning (the electrons from the cloud)
first of all, the actual electron drift in the lightning is very slow, just like in wires
what you're seeing is not a ton of electrons moving extremely fast from the air to the ground, but a lot of electrons moving very slowly in the same direction, what's moving extremely fast is electrical energy itself
secondly, after the discharge, the charge on the surface simply disperses evenly
Earth's surface has a charge of roughly -5 * 10^5 C, i.e. a net surplus of electrons
>>In step 3: Does the air at the point of "failing to be an insulator" become a conductor?
yes
dielectric breakdown, as it's called
>>Some sources have referenced a small area of positive charge at the absolute bottom of the cloud (see gif related), but their explanations didn't help - how is this small layer of positive charge relevant?
it will help the formation of a dielectrically broken down path for the lightning to discharge through, by building a "bridge" of sorts through which to discharge further down
if you watch lightning in slow-motion, you'll see that it spreads out "feelers" in a common fractal pattern known as a Lichtenberg figure as it descends, until one such feeler finally connects with the ground (and shortly before that happens, the ground can frequently be seen sending up visible feelers in the other direction too, depending on the strength of the lightning)
then there is a so-called "return stroke", which is essentially a cascade of electrical energy from the bottom and back up through the lightning, forming the visible bolt

Sleeping Beauty volunteers to undergo the following experiment and is told all of the following details: On Sunday she will be put to sleep. If the coin comes up tails, she will be awakened and interviewed on Monday and Tuesday.

In either case, she will be awakened on Wednesday without interview and the experiment ends.

Any time Sleeping Beauty is awakened and interviewed she will not be able to tell which day it is or whether she has been awakened before. During the interview Sleeping Beauty is asked: "What is your credence now for the proposition that the coin landed heads?"

posts.com: The Sailor's Child problem, introduced by Radford M. Neal, is somewhat similar. It involves a sailor who regularly sails between ports. In one port there is a woman who wants to have a child with him, across the sea there is another woman who also wants to have a child with him. The sailor cannot decide if he will have one or two children, so he will leave it up to a coin toss. If Heads, he will have one child, and if Tails, two children. But if the coin lands on Heads, which woman would have his child? He would decide this by looking at The Sailor's Guide to Ports and the woman in the port that appears first would be the woman that he has a child with. You are his child. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
If she thinks it is Monday when asked, it could be heads or tails.
If she thinks it is Tuesday when asked, it could only be heads.
If it is Wednesday, she is not asked.

So for Sleeping Beauty, if she is asked, she has one probability distributions to assess: is it Monday or a Tuesday. She cannot asses the probability of the coin, because it has already been tossed. From that probability distribution of Monday or Tuesday, she must decide the chances of heads. She has to see FROM the probability of what day it is TO the probability of the coin toss. She cannot see FROM the coin toss to what day it is because, if she is being asked, that means the coin has already been tossed, and she cannot know whether the probability of heads is 0% or 100%. There is no story where it is both. Therefore, she can only Enumerate all of the outcomes, and count heads.
So that is HT on Monday, but only H on Tuesday. But she does not know whether it is Monday or Tuesday, so she has to look at the TOTAL distribution for both days. The total for both days is HH and T. That makes it 2/3 heads and 1/3 tails.

Critical thinking requires understanding that the narrator’s position changes the story being told. That is why racists cannot understand CRT. It is impossible to assess the coin toss that has already been made, if you cannot see it. I wrote an easy to understand to simulation so you can stop fking arguing about this. Copy the code, press f12, paste it in you console, and press enter to run it on your machine.

let box1 = ["g", "g"];
let box2 = ["g", "s"];
let box3 = ["s", "s"];

let boxes = [box1, box2, box3];

let firstBallWasGoldCount = 0;
let nextBallWasSilverCount = 0;
let nextBallWasGoldCount = 0;

let numIterations = 1000;

for(let i = 0; i < numIterations; i++){
let chosenBox = boxes[Math.floor(Math.random() * 3)];
let chosenBall = chosenBox[Math.floor(Math.random() * 2)];

if(chosenBall == "g"){
firstBallWasGoldCount++;
if(chosenBox[0] == "g" && chosenBox[1] == "g") nextBallWasGoldCount++;
else nextBallWasSilverCount++;
}
}

console.log(`Times ran: ${numIterations}
Times first ball was gold: ${firstBallWasGoldCount}
Times next ball was gold: ${nextBallWasGoldCount}
Times nextBall was silver: ${nextBallWasSilverCount}\n
P(nextBallGoldGivenFirstWasGold)=${nextBallWasGoldCount/firstBallWasGoldCount}`);

>>15193571
Verbal IQ is your connection to language and linguistic manipulation. This gives you the ability to abstract complex objects into tidy concepts and also make very persuasive-sounding arguments. The problem is that those abstractions very frequently bear no connection to reality, and end up leading us toward convincing sophistry. To the verbal thinker, the ideas become more real than reality.

In contrast, spatial IQ is your connection to the real world, your ability to mentally envision, grasp, and manipulate complex objects directly. This is the faculty most crucial for expanding production and advancing technology.

In general, verbal thinkers will dominate groups like MBAs, administrators, lawyers, bankers, and rent-seekers. Spatial thinkers will dominate most areas of physics and engineering needed to industrialize.

There are exceptions though. For instance, verbal thinkers can make excellent pure mathematicians, because they don't have to worry about extracting "correct" axioms from the real word. The axioms are handed to them, and they just have to explore the ideas. However, in general I almost entirely blame the decline of western society on the current dominance of verbal thinking.

>>15194944
Longpost incoming (1/2):

I might concede that in a vacuum, verbal thinkers can provide better (or at least smoother and more agreeable) solutions to various types of social group dynamics. However, because we don’t live in a vacuum, they always in the process incur costs that far outweigh their benefits. This usually involves several types of problems:

1) Verbal thinkers will always drastically overestimate the importance of social interaction, management, “synergy” and all the other HR buzzwords in fostering efficient production.

2) Verbal thinkers will be too disconnected to anticipate the wider consequences of their actions. They will see a group dynamic problem, overestimate its importance, create an abstract model for that problem, and then determine a solution. That solution will not be abstract. It will be very much real, and it will require diversion of real resources from other problems to modify human behavior to the result they want.

3) Because their mental models of human psychology are usually wrong, they will barely move the needle, and the amount of resources they will require to achieve their utopian outcome will continuously increase. Because of the sunk cost fallacy, they will usually continue to get more resources and incur more collateral damage. And because of cognitive dissonance, they will dismiss any analysis of secondary consequences with more abstractions. We see this play out repeatedly. It is why every government program that fails gets rewarded with more funding.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>15195095
(2/2)
You put these principles together, and you get a world where corporations spend billions in resources every year on millions of HR workers, lawyers, bankers, and administrators while getting maybe 15% of that back in actual societal value. Where governments spend trillions every year on solving social problems with maybe 10% return on that investment. You get a research system with a massive replication crisis. You get an education system growing more radical and less objective. You get angry mobs who spout ideas about “equity” and “diversity” that are totally divorced from reality, vestiges of another verbal abortion known as “Blank Slate theory.”

In reality, society would so (SO) much better off if we put as little time and resources into those issues as possible, for two reasons:

1) Truly, the most Pareto efficient solution in the realm of social engineering is to do nothing, because human behavior is much more heritable and difficult to manipulate than ideologues want to believe.

2) The only human achievement which has meaningfully and consistently improved human socioeconomic conditions is technology. So again we are right back to spatial thinkers.

I’ll conclude this rant by just saying that you can look at something like the Pareto principle, Price’s law, Zipf’s law, etc., and see that the bulk of achievement and progress comes from a small subset of any given group, not some grand cultural synergy. Hard work and talent determine success, and there are no magic social shortcuts around that fact. I have no high hopes that humanity will break free from this death spiral, so we’ll continue to play around in 4th degree abstractions, and conditions will continue to get worse.

t. Physics PhD

It didn't need Gödel to arrive at the conclusion that "truth" is not something you can every be sure of, especially not in something like Arithmetic.
Just read Descartes.

Gödel's contribution is that for syntactic theories T, systems include at least Robinson arithmetic (arithmetic but not even induction, but with predecessor number existence), there will be sentences G such that you can't find a proof for either G or not(G).

Even if you hypothetically could prove such theory were consistent and if it were the case that it wouldn't have such Gödel sentences G, then we would still not be certain of any "truth". We'd just have a more neat axiomatic framework at hand. It's adoption - of the theory and interpretation of its implied inferences - is a choice on our side either way.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15194019
His result is a straight formal claim that in some structures (arithmetic theories in this case, with their strings of symbols and rules to move between them), the existence of certain computable paths (the proofs) is not consistent.
It tells us that if we were to find a sequence (of strings and rewrite rules in the theory T) with certain properties (e.g. proof of consistency of the arithmetized theory itself), then this mathematically means that this theory T has some other very unpleasent features. In that regard, his result isn't much different than any theorem in ring theory. And nothing we have to second guess. Just stick to the formal statement of "if a theory is nice in the sense of exhibiting X, then the theory also has the un-nice property Y".
It's a mathematical non-existence result that we can study also without describing its content in a trivializing liar-paradox kind of analogy.

>The incompleteness theorems apply to formal systems that are of sufficient complexity to express the basic arithmetic of the natural numbers and which are consistent and effectively axiomatized. Particularly in the context of first-order logic, formal systems are also called formal theories. In general, a formal system is a deductive apparatus that consists of a particular set of axioms along with rules of symbolic manipulation (or rules of inference) that allow for the derivation of new theorems from the axioms. One example of such a system is first-order Peano arithmetic, a system in which all variables are intended to denote natural numbers. In other systems, such as set theory, only some sentences of the formal system express statements about the natural numbers. The incompleteness theorems are about formal provability within these systems, rather than about "provability" in an informal sense.

>>15194448
you can argue that equivalents of AC are easier and more constructive in ZF+!C because !C gives you a set (like axiom of infinity) with certain specific properties instead of ruling out their existence
If you have !C, then you should be able to construct a set that has no well ordering using ZF and vice versa. There might be a nonconstructive proof, but it seems unlikely.
Also, I'm pretty sure ZF minus axiom of infinity plus negation of axiom of infinity is a perfectly reasonable theory, although I haven't investigated the details myself.
A "finite math" movement that studies this theory seems entirely reasonable, possibly even fashionable
Why not simply ban infinity? You can prove theorems about all of the sets in finite ZFC, as there are infinitely many of them, but each set is itself finite.
Note that C is a theorem of ZF-I+!I as we can just write down a choice function by induction.
In ZF-I+!I, ordinary induction serves to exhaust all sets, so at least in theory we have a big hammer we can use to build theorems
Also, you can just prove theorems about the set of hereditarily finite sets in ZFC
At least in theory, these are different topics, but one is a model of the other, in the sense of model theory

for example
let X* = { U[i=1]^n X[i] : { X[1],...,X[n] } is a finite subset of X }
and let X*^alpha = { U[beta<-alpha] f[beta] : f : alpha -> X is a map }
so X*^omega = X*

>choice-infinite: no choice function, doesn't have a choice function, yes we have no choice function, choice function is kill

Trends in breastfeeding basically go: rich people do one thing, 20 years later poor imitate them. Formula was sold as a miracle timesaver for the upper classes. They already through of breastfeeding as menial work, and hired wet nurses to do it for them. The invention of formula allowed them to fire their nurses. After that, it was discovered formula was severely deficient especially in certain fatty acid profile. By this time, the wealthy parents had already shifted back to breastfeeding, seeing it as now providing important emotional bonding as well as better physical health.

But because of this constant oscillation between trends among different social classes, the issue of breastfeeding is pretty fraught with accusations of classism, and the science is hardly objective unfortunately.

The science of breastfeeding is solid - it's excellent for the baby and should always be done if it's possible and safe for the baby. Breast milk transfers not just great nutrients that babies require, but specific immune complexes that help give them strong immune systems. The mother's immune system makes these complex compounds that the baby can't make yet and makes them less likely to get infections. Babies don't have fully formed or trained immune system organs that produce these immune compounds, and breast milk is the easiest way to provide them to the child.

Sadly many women aren't able to breastfeed, and there's some weird stigma to it, so western nations rely heavily on formula. Which works, but it's not natural or ideal or what's best for the baby. Breast feeding requires significant work, but it makes healthier children and modern medical scientific consensus has generally agreed it should be done if possible.

>>15191908
The computer is a language emulator. It is not a mathematics program. Moreover, even the most advanced mathematics programs and modules are very limited at best can only do what they could 20 years ago. That is, they can do relatively simple algebra and calculus computations that can be easily written as an algorithm but require direct input from a human user to organize and interpret these computations. Anything truly novel cannot be done by a computer at the moment (perhaps may never be done). Likewise, a computer cannot do a novel algorithm unless that algorithm is programmed into it. And most things unrelated to the Markov chains and so on used to procedural generate images and texts can only use what is already known.

if you can't even make the movement smooth in simulation, you should give up on making a sex bot. Smooth movement doesn't result from soft actuators. Power supplies that can supply upconvert like 9-12 volts to thousands of volts cost like a buck or too on aliexpress. These can't be controlled with a microcontroller, you'll need custom circuitry for that. Good luck controlling them once you have a controllable power supply

>>15184452
you take a plastic baggie. You glue tinfoil or literally anything slightly conductive on both sides, apply high voltage to both sides. Conductors attract each other and move fluid around, structure the right way and you've got muscle. It's that easy. You can get high voltage with one of these guys: https://www.aliexpress.us/item/2251832763430716.html
Get a switch that's plastic so you can turn it off without shocking yourself. These are very, very, very not isolated and will fry literally all electronics within a 5 foot radius, so don't expect to control them with a microcontroller. Use ionizer wire for one electrode and any other wire. It's so unisolated it doesn't really matter.

If [math] L=L(x) [/math] then this would just be a linear transformation [math] L=nx [/math] and in the case where [math] x=x(t) [/math] we would have:

[math] \frac{d^{2}L}{dt^2} = 0 [/math] Giving us a boundary condition on the curvature of the function. One of the solutions to the equation would be [math] \frac{\partial L}{\partial x_i}=(\frac{n^2}{3})^{1/2} [/math] for every i-th coordinate. And then:

[math] L(x,y,z) = (\frac{n^2}{3})^{1/2} (x+y+z) [/math] So it sounds like something that has to do with the energy of something expanding. My best guess is wave mechanics or some pulse radiating outwards. Maybe the energy or pressure the point at (x,y,z) feels at the time t.

In mathematics, small numbers are usually used to describe quantities that are close to zero but are not equal to zero. For example, .0001 is a small number because it is very close to zero. However, it is not equal to zero because it is an infinitely small magnitude. So, while it is extremely small, it can still be used for calculations and in other mathematical applications. Small numbers are often used in calculus and in other fields of math where we are working with functions that are very close to zero but do not cross the zero line exactly.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>15193960
What is "it" here?
The most clearcut definition in a theory without stratification of predicates, of the empty class, using set theory notation (not formally part of ZF),
[math]\{\}:=\{x \mid \neg(x=x)\}[/math]
Similarly, the most clearcut definition of the universal class is
[math]U:=\{x \mid x=x\}[/math]
Assuming the existence of any set B, assuming extensionality and assuming predicative separation without stratification,
We can define the set
[math]E:=\{x \mid \neg(x=x)\}[/math]
and further prove that E equals {}.

We can define the intersection of a set C by
[math]\bigcup C := \{x \mid \forall (A\in C). x\in A \}[/math]
This is apriori a class.
In fact it's not even a set if C={}.
For C={}, as shown above, it's actually the universal class U. I.e.
[math]\bigcup \{\} = U[/math]
So ZF theory is quite awkward as far as the set algebra is concerned.
(It makes sense to rather think of normal math as math on something like the Borel-sigma algebra, which has most things you'll need.)

(PS with epsilon induction and maybe some replacement, essentially U=V, where V is the class of von Neumann sets)

>>15194352
Wikipoodia probably explains the concept better than I can. Back in the time before Einstein it could be argued that time is not a legitimate dimension like the spatial dimensions, except in the dry sense that time is a coordinate used to describe a body's trajectory. But with relativity time is treated basically the same as space as part of a 4D spacetime, and its geometry determines simultaneity in different reference frames. So it makes sense to speak of different timepoints as equally real as different points in space.
